item.description:
DCR is holding workshops around the state to discuss proposed landscape designations on state properties. Here is a draft map DCR released in preparation for the meeting.

As you will see on the map, only 13% of land in Massachusetts' land is public land under the jurisdiction of DCR. With the new designations, 40% of those lands will be open to commercial logging through the "woodlands" designation. You can't count "parklands" as conservation areas since parklands are subject to heavy recreational use. While much of MSSF will be held in "Reserve", considering the amount of state lands left for forests and wildlife, we need to ask, is it enough?

Also, why isn't there a "patch reserve" designation; i.e., small areas of ecological importance inside parklands and woodlands deserving of protection? 

Please try to attend the workshop in our area. The workshops are open to anyone interested in the future management of DCR park land. The future of Massachusetts' forests and parks is up to you!

            Tuesday, June 7             Bristol County Agricultural High School             135 Center Street             Dighton             6:30 p.m. – 8:30 p.m. More information and a list of all the workshops

New Draft Designations:

Parklands = 75,478 acres for intensive recreational use

Reserves = 112,019 acres for nature—forests, birds, and wildlife—low impact recreation

Woodlands = 123,447 acres for commercial timber harvesting

group.name: Friends of Myles Standish State Forest Meetup Group

item.name: ATTEND SECOND WORKSHOP SERIES ON LANDSCAPE DESIGNATIONS FOR STATE PROPERTIES
